topic.para: When running a command prefaced with &sudo; for the first time, you are prompted for the &rootuser; password. This password remains valid for a certain period. Once it is expired, the user is prompted for the password again. To extend or shorten the time-out when executing commands that require &rootuser; privileges, make the following changes to your &sudo; configuration file.

note.title: Do not grant unlimited passwordless access to &rootuser; privileges

procedure.title: Changing the time-out for &sudo; password prompts

step.para: Create a new &sudo; configuration file for the timestamp configuration with:
After successful authentication with the &rootuser; password, the file is opened.
For more information on how to edit the &sudo; configuration file, refer to .
Enable editing and add the line timestamp_timeout=. Enter a value for the timestamp.
For example, to shorten the time-out to five minutes, enter:
If the timestamp is set to zero, you are be prompted for the &rootuser; password for every execution of a &sudo; command.
Save the changes and close the file.

topic.para: You have created a &sudo; configuration file and shortened the time-out setting for the execution of &sudo; commands.
